The answer is B. On the front end.

A dual-homed instance is an instance that has two network interfaces attached to it. This allows the instance to receive and process requests on both the front end and the back end. In this case, the front end is the mid-tier network where the application server resides. The back end is the network where the database server resides.

If the dual-homed instance receives and processes requests on the back end, then it would have to route network packets through itself. This would add unnecessary latency to the network traffic.

Selected Answer: B
Creating dual-homed instances with workloads/roles on distinct subnets
You can place a network interface on each of your web servers that connects to a mid-tier network where an application server resides. The application server can also be dual-homed to a backend network (subnet) where the database server resides. Instead of routing network packets through the dual-homed instances, each dual-homed instance receives and processes requests on the front end, initiates a connection to the backend, and then sends requests to the servers on the backend network.

A user has created a VPC with CIDR 20.0.0.0/16 using the wizard. The user has created a public subnet CIDR (20.0.0.0/24) and VPN only subnets CIDR
(20.0.1.0/24) along with the VPN gateway (vgw-123456) to connect to the user's data center. The user's data center has CIDR 172.28.0.0/12. The user has also setup a NAT instance (i-123456) to allow traffic to the internet from the VPN subnet.
Which of the below mentioned options is not a valid entry for the main route table in this scenario?

comments.content: The other options are valid entries for the main route table. Option A, Destination: 20.0.0.0/16 and Target: local, is a default route that routes all traffic within the VPC to the local instance. Option B, Destination: 0.0.0.0/0 and Target: vgw-123456, is a default route that routes all traffic outside of the VPC to the VPN gateway. Option C, Destination: 172.28.0.0/12 and Target: vgw-123456, is a route that routes traffic to the user's data center to the VPN gateway.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The answer is D. Destination: 20.0.1.0/24 and Target: i-123456.

The main route table is used to route traffic within the VPC. The destination CIDR in the route table entry specifies the range of IP addresses that the route applies to. The target specifies the gateway or instance that the traffic should be routed to.

In this scenario, the destination CIDR for option D, 20.0.1.0/24, is the CIDR for the VPN-only subnet. The target for option D, i-123456, is the NAT instance. However, the NAT instance is not used to route traffic to the VPN-only subnet. Instead, traffic to the VPN-only subnet is routed to the VPN gateway.
D. Destination: 20.0.1.0/24 and Target: i-123456

Download Router Configuration: This step involves downloading the router configuration from your AWS Direct Connect provider. This configuration file contains the settings for your virtual interface, but it does not include the customer-provided tag.
Complete the Cross Connect: This step involves connecting your on-premises network to the AWS Direct Connect location. This step does not involve tagging the virtual interface.
Configure Redundant Connections with AWS Direct Connect: This step involves configuring redundant connections between your on-premises network and the AWS Direct Connect location. This step does not involve tagging the virtual interface.

questions.question_text:
A user has created a VPC with CIDR 20.0.0.0/16 using the VPC wizard. The user has created public and VPN only subnets along with hardware VPN access to connect to the user's data center. The user has not yet launched any instance as well as modified or deleted any setup. He wants to delete this VPC from the console.
Will the console allow the user to delete the VPC?
questions.answer_description:
You can delete your VPC at any time (for example, if you decide it's too small). However, you must terminate all instances in the VPC first. When you delete a
VPC using the VPC console, Amazon deletes all its components, such as subnets, security groups, network ACLs, route tables, Internet gateways, VPC peering connections, and DHCP options. If you have a VPN connection, you don't have to delete it or the other components related to the VPN (such as the customer gateway and virtual private gateway).
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/VPC_Subnets.html#VPC_Deleting

choices.A: Yes, the user can detach the virtual private gateway and then use the VPC console to delete the VPC.
choices.C: Yes, the user can use the CLI to delete the VPC that will detach the virtual private gateway automatically.
choices.B: No, since the NAT instance is running, the user cannot delete the VPC.
choices.D: No, the VPC console needs to be accessed using an administrator account to delete the VPC.
